Yes, Colin thanks for for pointing out that CPPNs are a potential 
solution=
 to the problem modularity.  Colin, you're right that the 
word doesn't com=
e up much in the writings on the subject.  That's an 
interesting point.

I=
 think the reason I haven't used the word a lot is because the 
word "modul=
e" tends to give me a feeling of something that is 
explicitly and discrete=
ly defined.  For example, you can define 
an "arm" as a separate module and=
 then you can modify it 
independently or reuse it more than once.  

Yet w=
ith CPPNs we have been trying to avoid that particular brand of 
modularity=
, which I would call perhaps "brittle modularity."  If you 
look at the lit=
erature on modularity in EC, you will find a good deal 
of attempts to disc=
over explicit modules and then reuse them.  But 
what happens with such sys=
tems is you often can get an arm growing 
out of your head, because the enc=
oding has no sense of overall 
regularity or structure.

CPPNs on the other=
 hand offer a kind of "implicit modularity" in that 
you cannot point to a =
particular place in the encoding where any 
module is defined.  Yet, I do a=
gree that they are there at an 
implicit level.  For example, the spaceship=
 image always kept its 
wings and tail fins (once they were discovered), ev=
en as they changed 
and warped.  So in a sense, those were implicit modules=
 that were 
being maintained.  At least in comparison with nature, I believ=
e such 
dynamics better capture how natural modularity works.

In any case,=
 that is just to explain why I haven't been using the 
term much- it evokes=
 ideas of brittle modularity that I felt were the 
wrong concept.  Neverthe=
less, you rightly point out that in effect 
there is indeed a potential sol=
ution to the problem of modularity in 
the theory, and outside of the narro=
w semantics of my little research 
niche, it makes good sense to highlight =
that capability.

ken
